article.title: The variation of the maximal function of a radial function

response:
## Multiple Choice Quiz on "The Variation of the Maximal Function of a Radial Function"

**Figure/Formula 1:**

**(1.1)  M f(x) = sup_{B(z,r)ǝx} (1/|B(z,r)|) \int_{B(z,r)} |f(y)|dy =: sup_{B(z,r)ǝx} \fint_{B(z,r)} |f(y)| dy**

**Question:** Formula (1.1) defines which of the following?

a) The centered Hardy-Littlewood maximal operator
b) The non-centered Hardy-Littlewood maximal operator
c) The Sobolev norm of a function
d) The weak derivative of a function

**Answer: b)** The non-centered Hardy-Littlewood maximal operator

**Figure/Formula 2:**

**(1.2)  |DMcf(x)| ≤ Mc(|Df|)(x)**

**Question:** What does inequality (1.2) state about the centered Hardy-Littlewood maximal operator (Mc)?

a) It is bounded on LP(R) for 1 < p < ∞.
b) It is bounded in Sobolev-space W¹,r(R") if 1 < p < ∞.
c) It is not bounded in L¹.
d) It does not have a local maximum outside the set {Mf(x) = f(x)}.

**Answer: b)** It is bounded in Sobolev-space W¹,r(R") if 1 < p < ∞.

**Figure/Formula 3:**

**(1.3)  DM f(x) = \fint_B Df(y) dy**

**Question:**  This formula represents the derivative of the maximal function under what conditions?

a) For any function f ∈ L¹(R")
b) If Mf(x) = f(x) and |f(x)| < Mf(x) < ∞
c) If Mf(x) = fB |f|, |f(x)| < Mf(x) < ∞, and Mf is differentiable at x
d) For all radial functions f ∈ W1,1(Rn)

**Answer: c)** If Mf(x) = fB |f|, |f(x)| < Mf(x) < ∞, and Mf is differentiable at x

**Figure/Formula 4:**

**(1.4)  \int_B Df(y) · (y − x) dy = 0**

**Question:** What is the significance of equation (1.4) in the context of this paper?

a) It demonstrates the boundedness of the maximal operator in L¹.
b) It proves the main result of the paper, Theorem 3.11.
c) It highlights a key principle about weighted integrals of |Df| over B when the maximal function's value is attained at ball B.
d) It defines the auxiliary maximal function M¹.

**Answer: c)** It highlights a key principle about weighted integrals of |Df| over B when the maximal function's value is attained at ball B.
